text: Well, nothing more motivating than getting fired and told that my time was ending at day of A. So that kind of gets you to really contemplate new opportunities. I always had an entrepreneurial bent and I thought specifically that my own version of strategy, which some of our conversation has touched on, studying trades, really thinking about trade construction. I'm no economist, I'm following this stuff, but for me, trying to understand the markets fabric within the system of risk taking. In that period in 2007, things were getting funky. You really had to appreciate these cross-asset dynamics that I didn't think people did. I thought there was room for an independent provider of strategic insights, specifically in quantity stuff like derivatives. I also saw that the banks were pretty compromised. I saw that the banks were very compromised. I saw that there was a lot of They had books of bad exposures at the wrong price. And it's very difficult to continue to be a bona fide liquidity provider to your clients when you're nursing mark to market risk that is scary when vol is in the 50s and 60s. And so I thought that there was a chance to start an independent firm that was an agency broker that didn't have capital itself, but again, back to the moving business, not the storage business, knew how to arrange trades and find liquidity, and then just try to be good at one or two things. And I think what I would say about Macro Risk Advisors is we've tried to stick to our knitting of helping people think about whether the VIX is too high or too low. What are the factors moving it around? Helping people construct trades that do what they want them to. I always would get emails from clients saying, hey, I just got shown this one by two puts spread from a bank or a competitor, and they're telling me this is a hedge. And I'd say, so you're buying one put, but selling two downside puts against it. Let's see, let's shock prices down by X and vol up by X, and let's see how this thing looks at a mark to market basis. No, that's not a hedge. So I think arbitrage is a really hard thing to come by, but I do think you can find ways to get the trade to do what you want it to do. Yeah. And I think that's the key to success. I think the key to success is specific to each counterparty, so it's getting to know your clients. And then I always say, take what the vol surface gives you. There's term structure, there's skew, there's cross asset proxies, maybe using other instruments than the S&P, maybe the HYG is a good proxy. So it's just trying to be creative and thoughtful about how you might spend option premium or how you might implement a trade that's programmatic, a bit mechanical. How do you think about unwinding trades? And then the second part is just trust and hustle. It's sales trading. So the folks that I'm lucky enough to work with are experts with using technology. You got to be an expert at implementing the system's split second judgment on whether to use the screens or to call three counterparties and see if you can get a price. Sometimes it's doing both of those at the same time, so it could be a two to three man process of really representing your clients. I find from nothing like it. I think about looking at some of the points like you haven't also, Josh, you're telling us to pay attention in the right hands, I'm not, not that, you know, that's not what it It's not just, you know, even with basking in the sponge. It's a little hard, but what I like about that. It's something that's really very valuable and I think sort of rhythmically basically me riding the lead. Sure. as if it's our own. So we have a system. Once the trade is done, it goes in our system. Our head of trading, Adam Knoth, monitors these trades exhaustively. Maybe the client did a put spread and the lower leg has decayed in value and you could get it back for seven cents. And point that out, right? Just be on the ready. Sometimes these folks have a ton to do. So you're really an outsourced source of trading. You're their eyes and ears trying to find levels. It's really trying to help them with their day-to-day. And that could be any number of things, but it's really to work alongside your counterparties. And again, I think a lot of the backbone of this is trying to earn and keep trust. That's what keeps the client to me coming back.
